channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers, science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you. They deliver cost-efficient genotyping technology that promotes the development of better, stronger crops adapted to suit their environment. They're looking for programers that are familiar with modern tooling and might have experience with Ansible, AWS, and Linux containers.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries.With a website that allows consumers to compare deals on everything from toasters to tablets, our client helps their users hunt out the best values. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. They’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who has both strong Perl and Python.

item.title: Change the world without leaving your desk! Remote Perl role - UK, Switzerland or South Africa
item.description: As a thriving multinational fundraising group, our client works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools to connect with their supporters. In addition to strong Modern Perl, candidates should be experienced with payment networks, systems, and bank file formats like ISO 20022, SWIFT MT940/942 and NACHA ACH, and experience with Unix/Linux and shell scripts.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 128
item.description: Simon broke the task into smaller action giving us clear instructions to read the code. Always pleasure to read the blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 128: Maxima and Minima
item.description: Roger style of inline document is very useful to follow the code. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 128
item.description: The best oart Luis blog is the use of PDL. Cool promotion of PDL. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 128: to much complex?
item.description: Luca also used Raku class to solve the Minimum Platfor task. I just love it. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #128
item.description: James genomic approach to Minimum Platform solution is really cool. There is plenty to learn from his work. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC128 - Minimum Platforms
item.description: Flavio gone into the finer details of the Minimum Platforms. I wonder at times, how did I miss the point.

item.title: PWC128 - Maximum Sub-Matrix
item.description: Flavio once again sharing bonus Raku magic along with Perl. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: MinMaxing Matrix Platforms: The Weekly Challenge 128
item.description: Well documented solution, as always, with edge cases as well. A complete solution. Thanks.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #128
item.description: A very special presentation of Minimum Platform task, complete with unit test. Great job.

item.title: With Raku to Mum's Platform
item.description: A cool example of Raku class. Great demo of Raku best practices. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 128: Minimum Platforms
item.description: A very special solution to the Minimum Platform task as you get to see the Abigail magic, once again. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 128: Maximum Sub-Matrix
item.description: Nice demo of code reuse. I didn't know, to be honest, it is somewhat repeat of past task.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 126
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 128
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Maximum Sub-Matrix" and "Minimum Platforms" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 129
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Root Distance" and "Add Linked Lists". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Today I Learned: Portable Grayscale Map
item.description: Flavio discuss something I never touched before. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Taming the Moose: Method modifiers instead of overrides in object-oriented Perl
item.description: If you are Moose fan then please do checkout the blog discuss about method modifiers.

item.title: Migrating a Perl CGI to AWS Lambda
item.description: A very detailed blog talking about every aspects of migration of CGI to AWS.

item.title: Corinna RFC
item.description: Rough table of contents for the Corinna RFC by Curtis

item.title: #528 - Legacy Code
item.description:
Hi there

How old is your Perl code that you work on currently?

Curtis wrote an interesting blog talking about dealing with legacy code.

After a long time, I got the opportunity to work with good old CGI. It reminds me the early learning days. Talking about CGI, I came across fun blog talking about Migrating a Perl CGI to AWS Lambda.

Please do share anything interesting you are trying using Perl. I am currently working on Elastic Search using Perl. As always CPAN provides great support e.g. Search::Elasticsearch.

What else change happened in the routine?

For me, school run is back. How about you?

Enjoy rest of the newsletter. Hopefully next week will have more perl blogs.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
